MUMBAI: The outlook for the Indian steel sector is bright with key brokerages hiking target price and upgrading stocks on the back of strong demand and rising prices.

In the past few days, Morgan Stanley has upgraded the ratings of Jindal Steel to overweight from underweight and increased the target price to Rs 188 from Rs 174. It also upgraded the ratings of JSW Steel and Sail to equalweight from underweight and increased the target price of JSW Steel to Rs 296 from Rs 278 and Sail from Rs 53 to Rs 54. Goldman Sachs also upgraded the ratings of JSW Steel to buy from neutral with a target price of Rs 315.

Analysts increasingly feel that large steel stocks currently trading at marginal discounts to long term average EV/EBITDA could be best bets. “Indian steel industry on the cusp of a multi-year run,” said Chetan Phalke, CIO – Alpha Invesco. “It’s a time to take a contrarian bet due to strong domestic steel prices, rising capacity utilizations, de-leveraging of the balance sheets and governments anti-dumping duties till 2022”.

Jindal Steel & Power, Tata Steel, JSW Steel and Sail have underperformed the Sensex between 15 per cent and 50 per cent in the past one year. These stocks now trade between 5 and 6 times FY 2019 estimated EV/EBITDA as against the historical average of 7x.



Demand has been strong in India but production has been affected by sluggish exports. Rating agency ICRA said recently that Indian steel demand will grow at over 7 per cent while World Steel Association last year upped its 2019 India growth forecasts to 7.3 per cent from 6 per cent.

Steel prices have firmed up on the back of these government measures and firm domestic demand while international prices too have recovered. Monthly production growth has accelerated in the last two months after a long stagnation.

The favorable risk-reward scenario has prompted the upgrades, analysts said.

“Demand recovery from recent lows and price rises led by global steel prices and domestic demand should support earnings growth for Indian steel companies and drive stock performance,” said Ashish Jain, equity analyst, Morgan Stanley India. “Stock valuations too are supportive, with large steel stocks now at marginal discounts to longterm average EV/EBITDA and a modest premium on price-to-book of 20 per cent now versus 50 per cent three months ago”.

Domestic demand grew 7.5 per cent in December 2018 quarter and while it moderated in January 2019. Analysts expect demand recovery on the back of industrial capex and some pick up in consumption demand. The industry has raised steel prices by 4 per cent or Rs 1,500 per tonne in the past month. With Indian steel prices now at a marginal discount to the import parity price vs an 8 per cent premium in Nov-18, price risk is skewed to the upside, according to analysts.

“We expect divergent near and medium term steel price trajectory in CY 2019 with an expected near term upswing led by higher iron-ore prices due to Vale disruption, restocking in China and strengthening CNY/US$,” said Abhishek Poddar, analyst, Kotak Securities.

Kolkata: A 30% surge in global iron ore prices to $90 a tonne this month following disruption in supply at top producer Vale’s mines in Brazil, is expected to benefit Indian miners, according to industry analysts.

With steel demand estimated to grow at a robust rate of 5.5-6.5%, domestic miners are poised to maintain strong prices through the first half of 2019, a recent Crisil Research report said.

India Ratings & Research (Ind-Ra) also said revocation of the licence at the Brazilian mine would be favourable for Indian miners and steel producers in the short term.

Local miners have announced price hikes of Rs 600-700 per tonne for 62% Fe fines and Rs 800-900 per tonne for pellets in February. “We foresee domestic iron ore prices rising 3-4% during calendar year 2019. This would have a direct bearing on 62% of the steel production that is based on supply from merchant (non-captive) miners,” said Prasad Koparkar, senior director of CRISIL Research.

“With domestic steel prices expected to soften following global cues, there would be pressure on margins of steel makers, especially long steel producers, who do not have captive iron ore supply impacting their gross spreads by 2-4%,” he added.



Ind-Ra said it expects ore prices to firm up since imports would now be expensive and importers in India might source the raw material from domestic miners, leading to a demand-supply mismatch. It added the rise in ore prices could put pressure on the margins of steel players like JSW Steel, Jindal Steel & Power and Rashtriya Ispat Nigam that do not have captive mines, unlike Steel Authority of India and Tata Steel.

Ratings firm ICRA, however, estimates domestic ore output to touch 211 million tonnes in the current fiscal year with an oversupply of around 25 million tonnes, thereby limiting any price hike. It added that the situation was unlikely to change materially until around March 31, 2020 when most of the merchant mining leases would expire. Crisil felt iron ore mining auctions of 80 million tonnes in April 2020 will slow the price tempo from Q4FY20 as merchant miners maximise output before the deadline.

While India’s iron ore imports rose one-and-a-half times to about 11.8 million tonnes between April and December 2018, it is likely to be a short-term phenomenon, Crisil said, citing firm global ore prices during H1FY19 and a ramp-up in captive production by large players.

MUMBAI: JSW Steel has entered into a 5-year Advance Payment and Supply Agreement (APSA) with Duferco International Trading Holding (DITH) for a consideration of 700 million dollars in a move that will help the steel company in funding its growth plans, the company announced on Friday.

JSW Steel will be required to provide "committed exports of steel products" to the Swiss steel trader DITH for the said period that will assure the latter of a "captive supply of various steel products from JSW". 

This arrangement between the two parties makes it the largest trade finance deal to have been arranged in the Indian steel sector and is inked at a time when JSW Steel has emerged as the winning bidder for the stressed steel company Bhushan Power and Steel for which it has reportedly offered Rs 19,650 crore. 

“The structured long-term trade finance transaction is an important deal in diversifying the sources of financing for JSW Steel," Seshagiri Rao, joint MD of JSW Steel said in a release. 

"This not only enables JSW to raise funds at competitive rates but also assures incremental volume of sales in export markets leveraging the wide spread global network of the DITH Group Companies. This transaction is a win-win for both the organisations," Rao added. 

The deal has been arranged and financed by global banks like BNP Paribas, Citibank, Credit Suisse, ING, Mashreqbank, Natixis, Societe Generale, Standard Chartered Bank acting as Mandated Lead Arrangers and bookrunners. 

"...(the deal) corroborates our faith in the sustainability of steel trading and indeed is a material statement of confidence in the reliability of our partner JSW. We look forward to facilitating JSW’s existing and future steel exports to a diverse and multinational customer base," Matthew De Morgan, chief executive at DITH Group said. 

DITH Group is an independent trader and a major distributor and processor of steel products and associated raw materials. JSW Steel and Duferco had earlier had a prepayment deal in 2006 for $150 million for a period of seven years.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 15.50 points, or 0.14 per cent, lower at 10,832, indicating a negative start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today’s session:


RCom: Reliance Communications (RCom) has dialled telecom secretary Aruna Sundararajan, calling on the department of telecommunications (DoT) to issue a no objection certificate (NoC) to its pending spectrum trading deal with Reliance Jio Infocomm.


GAIL: The Centre has nominated state-run GAIL to buy the gas output from Vedanta’s prolific Barmer block, which has recently begun pumping the energy resource after accounting for a fourth of India’s domestic crude oil production.


Adani Gas: Oil regulator PNGRB has rejected Adani Gas's application for authorisation to retail CNG to automobiles and piped natural gas to households in Jaipur and Udaipur, saying the company was not in compliance with regulations for a licence.


IDBI Bank: The IDBI Bank has received government nod to handle import and export transactions with Iran, a move which would help in promoting two-way trade amid US sanctions on the Persian Gulf nation, industry sources said.


Central Bank of India: State-owned Central Bank of India has put up for sale four stressed accounts, including Bhushan Power & Steel and Essar Steel India, to recover dues of Rs 3,321 crore.


ONGC: State-owned ONGC has received just one bid from US oilfield-service company Schlumberger Ltd for its ambitious pilot to raise output from ageing oilfields through the infusion of technology, sources with direct knowledge of the development said.


Aurobindo Pharma: The company has completed the acquisition of seven marketed oncology injectable products, intellectual property and commercial infrastructure from Spectrum Pharmaceuticals Inc, a US-based global branded oncology company by Acrotech Biopharma.


Reliance Industries: Subsidiary Reliance Industrial Investments and Holdings Limited (RIIHL) acquired software company C-Square Info Solutions Private Limited and logistics services platform company Grab A Grub Services Private Limited.


DLF: Realty major DLF's sales bookings are likely to jump more than two-fold to around Rs 2,400 crore this fiscal year on rising demand of completed housing units. DLF, the country's largest realty firm in terms of market capitalisation, also expects to sell its finished housing inventories worth Rs 12,500 crore in the next 3-5 years, depending on the market conditions, it's group CFO Ashok Tyagi said.


ICICI Bank: ICICI Bank said it will acquire 9.9 per cent stake in non-banking finance company Kisan Finance for cash consideration of Rs 17.82 crore.


LIC Housing: The company has partnered with India Mortgage Guarantee Corporation (IMGC) to offer special loan scheme under which borrowers can repay the amount till the age of 75 years.


Welspun Corporation: State-owned LIC has brought down its stake in Welspun Corporation to 5.54 per cent by selling shares in the open market. According to a regulatory filing by Welspun Corp, LIC which held 2,04,82,544 shares, or 7.72 per cent, sold 57,89,140 shares or 2.18 stake in the company.


Karnataka Bank: The Reserve Bank of India has imposed a total monetary fine of Rs 8 crore on three banks - Karnataka Bank, United Bank of India and Karur Vysya Bank - for non-compliance of directions on Swift messaging software.


Voltas: Tata group firm Voltas expects its home appliances business to capture at least 20 percent market share in the next five-seven years.


JSW Steel: The company said it has inked a 5-year advance payment and supply agreement with Duferco International Trading Holding for USD 700 million. The pact executed on 27 February entails a financing structure, which will provide "JSW long term funding to complement its plans for future growth secured by committed exports of steel products to DITH," JSW Steel said in a statement.


NTPC: State-run power giant NTPC has decided to acquire only those stressed power projects undergoing insolvency proceedings in the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT), with an aim to get fairer deals.


NLC India: The company said it has commissioned the entire 500 MW solar power projects in Tamil Nadu.

NEW DELHI: Weak global sentiment extended to the Indian equity market as benchmarks Sensex and Nifty opened in the negative territory on Tuesday in the absence of any major domestic trigger.

Renewed concerns over slowing global growth as China cut its economic growth target and signs of a slowdown in the US economy weighed on investor sentiment even as the ongoing US-Cina trade talks are yet to bear any fruit.

Asian shares stepped back on Tuesday, weighed by US growth concerns and as China cut its economic expansion target amid growing challenges from rising debt and a dispute over trade and technology with the United States, Reuters reported.

However, a fall in crude oil prices and rupee's tepid gain against the US dollar capped the losses for the market.

The rupee was trading 6 paise higher at 70.85 against the US dollar due to some selling in American currency by banks and exporters.

Sensex fell over 130 points in early deals but pared most losses and traded 42 points, or 0.12 per cent, down at 36,021.60 around 9:30 am. The Nifty index was 11 points, or 0.10 per cent, down at 10,852 at that time.

Meanwhile, midcaps and smallcaps outpaced Sensex, rising 1 per cent each.

Tata Steel, Tata Motors, Coal India and Hero MotoCorp were leading among the Sensex gainers. On the flip side, Larsen & Toubro, Bharti Airtel, Mahindra & Mahindra, HDFC and Bajaj Finance were among the top losers. Among the 31 stocks (including Tata Motors DVR) in the Nifty kitty, 15 were in the green and 16 were in the red. 

BSE Metal index jumped over 1 per cent, leading the pack of sectoral gainers. All components of the index were trading with gains. Nalco, SAIL, Jindal Steel, JSW Steel, Tata Steel and NMDC climbed between 1 per cent to 4 per cent.

Foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) bought Rs 198.38 crore worth of domestic stocks on Friday, data available with NSE suggested. DIIs were net buyers to the tune of Rs 117.05 crore, data suggested. 

Meanwhile, MSCI India’s weight in the MSCI Emerging Market index is likely to fall 20 basis points by end of November this year to 8.2 per cent, assuming a 50 per cent inclusion factor for China A- Shares, said Goldman Sachs. 

“This could lead to potential outflows of $3.8 billion (active + passive) from MSCI EM tracking funds,” said Goldman Sachs in a note, retaining 'market weight' stance on Indian equities.

Prasanth Prabhakaran, Senior President & CEO, YES Securities, believes that there will be a derating of most of NBFCs by rating agencies and analysts. He laid bare the preference for corporate finance banks such as ICICI and Axis. He spoke to ETNow. 


Edited excerpts:


Within large caps, would you say it is going to be more a broad based move or again the move is going to be narrow, the six-seven stocks are performing?

So, we have chosen sectors. Let me not say sectors, it is stocks that we like in this space. We continue to like the corporate finance ones, which are your ICICI and Axis, and the preference is given to Axis because of the focus towards growth rather than sustenance that ICICI is trying. they are basically trying to maintain and not falter too much whereas Axis has decided to put growth path on their radar. 

Then you have L&T as a pick in the same space, thanks to also the infra spending that has happened and the fact that their businesses are more broad based and their credit cycles have become shorter. It is a more lucrative business. They have cut margins, but they have made sure the cycles are shorter which is core of the business that they have functioned with. Lastly, in the space that is there, it is a momentum move that has continued in the steel sector and so we are bullish on JSW Steel in that space. 

We have stuck to the largecaps, but specific ones. I do not think it is sector wise that we have gone ahead with. There is only one midcap that we have in our pick at this point of time and that is Birla Corp and that too because of the fact that they are central India focussed and they have a lot of infra projects that have come in out there. That is more or less the basket we have gone ahead with.



Let us take a look also in terms of what we are seeing in the IT pack and a lot of strength that seems to be building out there. What is your take on that in terms of the potential going forward, whether or not it is a defensive play or there is genuinely scope here to see more room for growth as well?

In the IT sector, you have two picks that we have when we continue to have over the last quarter or so, which has given results for most of our clients. It remains TCS in the large cap space that we have taken and Persistent in the midcap space, both because of the futuristic move they have made towards products. Because that is where the margins are going to lie, that is where demand lies, that is where you are going to make sure the differentiation between you and the next player. 

You stick to these sectors because of the simple fact that it is not a three-month or a six-month view. This is a good two-year view. They have managed to transform themselves at TCS. They had hardly around 4-5 per cent of their top line coming in from their businesses which were apart from services. 

Around 23-25% of their top line now comes in from their product businesses and allied businesses, the digital business that they have talked about. So interesting stories to play out and it will continue to hold good for some more time.


I understand you are suggesting to buy corporate banks and the mess through which NBFCs have gone. The one beneficiary pocket of this mess has been corporate banks because that is where more lending would start because NBFCs are dealing through their problems. Going through your note, you are saying liquidity issues in NBFCs will get better now. I understand you have hands-on experience of functioning of NBFCs. Just for our viewers, please explain what is happening in the NBFC space at this point when it comes to liquidity and also if you feel that liquidity pressure is going to ease. Which are those NBFCs and let us not get into consumer NBFCs like Bajaj Finance and Bajaj Finserv of the world? Which are the NBFCs which would capitalise on this liquidity enhancement which would happen in the near future?


What clients need to understand is that the last two quarters have gone by post around September when the crisis actually started off. Most of the NBFCs were lending for a long term, but they had been borrowing for short term because they get cheaper rates to borrow either from a bank or a mutual fund or by CPs that they had issued or by way of NCDs. 

So you have a six-year book, 10-year book based on whether it is a housing loan that you have given or whether it is a car loan or some other short term loan. 

So how do you start lending again, how do you build a book, how do you comeback into growth, those are the concerns that NBFCs have which will continue over the next one odd quarter. By the time the situation will ease off, there is no default and there will be confidence which will come back into the money markets and there will be lending which will start again to this sector. 

It is a crucial segment, it is practically around 30-35 per cent of the retail lending space which is catered to by these players. So it is a crucial area, it needs to be watched. 

Actually one of the NBFCs we have is CanFin Homes. It is a pure retail lending play in the NBFC space. It is among the very few that we have chosen apart from obviously the large ones like HDFC Ltd. because of the pedigree and the way they have been able to manage raising funds and deploying it also.

Does the move so far and especially the kind of broader market recovery that we have seen of late, does it look deceiving and do you think it is going to falter soon or is it looking a little bit more convincing this time?

So the good portion is that it has given a lot of relief to a lot of HNIs which have been beaten black and blue as far as midcaps and smallcaps are concerned. There is a lot of relief on that side. But it is a little too premature. 

There are still events that are supposed to flow out in the next quarter or so, which includes the elections, liquidity push and as far as NBFC is concerned, they have still not seen an end to it and lastly the pickup of economy which is the last portion of it. In this, elections seems to be moving towards a consensus and that will firm up the moment your election season is over. 

As far as liquidity is concerned, the NBFCs that we have spoken to have managed to tide over the short-term crisis. Now the growth will happen, but there will be a derating of most of NBFCs by the rating agencies and analysts. So you will have some pain there. My belief is that you are in the top end of the spectrum as far as valuations are concerned. 

You will again see a range between 10,400 and 11,100-11,200. In that range, your markets will ease off and it will start picking up from the bottom post the Q1 getting over anywhere. It is around that period that we will expect the markets to start taking off and you should build up a portfolio for the long term in the midcap space. The next quarter is a largecap space that I will stick to because midcaps have run up way ahead of their fundamentals at this point.

ET Intelligence Group: Shares of state-owned steel producer SAIL surged 15 per cent in the past three trading sessions, given its 15-year low valuations and captive iron ore mines, with investors becoming bullish about the prospects of the primary infrastructure alloy.

International steel prices have risen 15 per cent since January on the back of a surge in global iron ore prices. Spot iron ore prices have climbed 30 per cent after Vale, the world’s largest iron ore producer, shut its Brazilian mines due to a dam collapse, causing supply disruption. Analysts are assuming a near 45 MT net production loss in 2019, which could keep iron prices rather high.

SAIL, which owns 100 per cent captive iron ore, is not affected by the rise in raw material prices. While the situation is turning favourable, the stock is near 15-year low on valuations despite improving operational performance. EBITDA per tonne for SAIL in December was Rs 7,965, the highest in last eight years. At the current price of Rs 54, the stock is trading at 0.5 times price to book. This has put the stock on the radar of many traders.



The reason for higher per tonne EBITDA is control on high wage costs. Employee expense has been coming down consistently since FY15 – down by over 10 per cent from FY15 to FY18. Employee cost to sales in FY18 was down to 15.5 per cent from 25 per cent in FY16. In the first nine months of FY19, it was 13.5 per cent. Analysts expect lower employee costs to sustain.

Also, over the last few years, SAIL has disappointed on the capex growth – delay in setting up blast furnaces and rolling mills. However, the company addressed this issue with the completion of a Rs 70,000-crore capex and is producing 16 MT annually.

Still, several industry experts believe that products of its peers could be superior, constraining potential realisations at SAIL. Its first nine month sales fell by 14 per cent as compared to other companies such as JSW Steel, which saw only a 7 per cent drop in volumes. Analysts expect a 10 per cent jump in volumes for SAIL in FY20, and that could be at risk. Also, in that case, debt to EBIDTA could touch as high as 4. The company has net debt of about Rs 44,000 crore.

The rise in sales in the December quarter was due to higher average realisations (steel prices started falling only after October). For the December quarter, its sales increased by 3.3 per cent to Rs 15,836 crore. EBIDTA grew by 79 per cent to Rs 2,526 crore.

Macros turning in favour of the company could take the stock price higher, something traders would cheer. But long-term investors should do a detailed analysis before buying at the current market price.

The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) Friday directed the Delhi bench of the NCLT to decide over JSW Steel's bid for the debt-ridden Bhushan Power & Steel by March 31. A two-member NCLAT bench headed by Chairman Justice S J Mukhopadhaya has also directed the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) to hear the representatives of operational creditors, promoters along with dissenting banks also. 

"We expect adjudicating authority (NCLT) to decide the case at an early date to ensure that the matter is decided before the end of this financial year," the appellate tribunal said.

During the proceedings, Bhushan Power promoter Sanjay Singal through his counsel offered to settle all dues of the lenders. 

On this, the appellate tribunal has directed NCLT to also take a decision over Singal's offer to settle. 

"Liberty is given to adjudicating authority to decide who should be heard as representative of operational creditors or promoters or dissenting financial creditors, if any," it said. 

Earlier, on February 4 the NCLAT had dismissed the plea of Tata Steel and upheld lenders' decision to approve resolution plan of JSW Steel for Bhushan Power & Steel. 

Tata Steel had challenged an NCLT order that had allowed the CoC of Bhushan Power and Steel to the resolution plan submitted by Liberty House Group. Tata Steel had contended that NCLT cannot provide numerous opportunities at the belated stage. 

The NCLAT had said the Committee of Creditors' (CoC) decision was well within its rights to negotiate better terms with resolution applicants. 

JSW Steel had revised its offer from Rs 11,000 crore to Rs 18,000 crore and later to over Rs 19,000 crore, whereas Tata Steel's last offer was at Rs 17,000 crore after it had refused to revised its bid.

IT pack is now showing good strength with growth ranging from 3% to 6% on constant currency growth quarter on quarter, said 
Yogesh Mehta, Vice-President, Motilal Oswal Financial Services Ltd, in an interview with ET Now. Edited excerpts: 


Would the prospects of Arvind Fashion interest you?
There are quite a few good brands available in that segment. But enterprise value and EV to EBITDA as the profit margin for FY19, if we consider the full year, is not much and on the top line basis, it is hardly 6% as a bottom line in comparison with any of the listed companies. There are very few companies in a similar sector, similar category or the industry sector. 

We believe it would not be prudent enough to comment right now and on an enterprise value basis, it is quite expensive if we consider what the opening price would be. But then also, on the EV to EBITDA basis and debt to EBITDA basis, it is quite expensive. We believe one should wait and watch rather than jumping into the bandwagon right now on the listing day.


We were just looking at the prospects for Tata Motors and again this seems to be a bit of cagey situation. Just when Chandra was talking about strategy for Tata Motors and prioritising JLR, the fact that ECB has pegged down its own and global growth forecast does not spell good news for JLR?
We also believe that earlier Tata Motors had a concern with the US and now it is a concern with Europe vis-a-vis Brexit and China post the US-China trade war problems, So, that is now a dampener. The Tata Motors sales numbers which came out yesterday show 4-4.5% decline on the wholesale side. The way they have projected the third quarterly numbers and when there is a one-time write off of Rs 26,000-27,000 crore and the visibility for JLR is not so promising on the global front right now will create a hurdle for the company though the domestic scenario has improved a bit. But remember, 85% of the balance sheet is from the global side. 

We believe that at Rs 190-195 odd, it leaves very limited room for upside unless and until we see good growth over next two-three quarters and post it may we revisit but at Rs 190-200, it seems that it will be fairly priced considering the balance situation or positions right now.


How will the currency factor play out for IT sector? Nasscom’s projections are coming in. How will all of this news impact the IT sector and which are your bets?
The IT pack is now showing good strength with growth ranging from 3% to 6% on constant currency growth quarter on quarter. The numbers which have delivered in the third quarter as well shows strong momentum with multi-million deal wins by even Infosys.

Even TCS and Tech Mahindra seem to have a very stable kind of earnings growth and probably the EPS growth would be in the range of 10% to 12%. Cost rationalisation and digitisation will give a strong push to this business vertical. We believe all these are companies where top pick would remain Infosys. 

All these companies are cash rich and they are doing buybacks and that is additional advantage for investors so that gives a strong confidence for the investors on the growth story as well as the investment rational. We believe Infosys would be the top pick in largecap category and in mid to largecap category, Tech Mahindra would be the best bet.


How are you reading into the block deals that we are anticipating. We were talking about ICICI Pru and how with the promoters are looking to sell stake in this one. Reports indicate that the Azim Premji Trust is looking to sell nearly 26 million shares. What is your take on both of these stories?
On the first part, in Wipro, the promoters’ stake is nearly about SEBI’s preferred guidelines of 75%. They are selling it for the stake monetisation. But we believe on the business side again it is growing with 6% to 7% growth rate and a strong case of investment can be made from here. Since it has a Rs 56,000-odd-crore reserve for FY19 and FY20 would be a little more than that, the PAT is growing again by 8 to 10 percentage. 

On the block deal side, at Rs 355-360, whatever the price may be, around this level again it will be a good opportunity for investors to get into the stock. It has got ex-bonus and so it is available at Rs 255-260. But again, post ex-bonus, it is a strong case for buyback in near future. I would say that at around Rs 250-260 levels, it will be a good opportunity for investors to get into.

Secondly on ICICI Pru: ICICI Bank needs to restructure their balance sheet on the NPA numbers and to do away with these provisions. They need to sell the stake in ICICI Pru which was expected in near future which has come off recently. We believe that the third quarter results or in the first nine months of ICICI Pru, there was a dip into the market share in the overall peer category. Secondly, on private players, both the sides they have lost the market share significantly and new business premium is also slowing down to 9% to 10% level. 

We give two times embedded value and also on the higher side, it could be Rs 400 on FY21 basis. So at around Rs 300 or sub-300 would be a good opportunity to get into as an investment.


Do you believe that one would be a tad circumspect on the metal sector’s prospects given what is going on globally? It is a fairly cyclical space and there has been a bit of under performance within this pack as well?
For the metal sector, we believe growth is now plateauing and aluminium or steel demand is not growing. The capacity which has already been built globally as well as domestically. The businesses are available at a very reasonable prices right now post the correction, we believe strong projections and growth story for the domestic infrastructure and the construction businesses post in the second half or may be the early start of 2020 will drive demand. 

It seems that post the correction, it gives us strong case of investment even in Hindalco, even in JSW Steel or the Jindal Steel Power where the debt level are reasonable rather than Tata Steel. We believe this is a good strong point for investment here in metal sector from current price looking at more than one to two years kind of a horizon and not on the immediate basis.

Last week, the world’s largest private residential ship docked in Mumbai. Called ‘The World’, it has 165 luxury residences on board, owned by wealthy businessmen from across the world. The owners often spend a part of the year on the ship and others can book the residences during the remaining period. Only housekeeping comes free on the ship run by a Florida-based company flying the flag of The Bahamas.

Of the 165 residences, some are owned by Indian-origin businessmen. The ship travels across the world — the route decided after a vote among the residents — and offers entertainment, sports and a choice of half-a-dozen restaurants. This year, the ship made four stops in India before sailing for Oman. A businessperson, who recently attended a dinner onboard the cruise ship, says there was a palpable interest among the residents about India as a manufacturing hub, and some said they were already buying more from India than from China.


 The Nikkei Purchasing Manager’s Index that indicates the degree of confidence in the manufacturing sector also signals a revival in factory output in India. For February, the PMI was at 54.3 — a 14-month high. It has been going up for three months now.

Not only manufacturing PMI but services PMI too along with overall business confidence index have moved up in the last three months. Predictions are that the indices will go higher as the country enters poll season.

But the question is: can India’s private sector make the most of these tailwinds? And is it in a position to do so? Will this lead to fresh capital investments?

Consider the impact of a significant drop in GDP growth rate. Economic growth for the current financial year touched a six-quarter low of 6.6% in the September-December period, dropping from 8.2% in April-June and 7.1% in July-September.

Ajit Ranade, chief economist at the Aditya Birla Group, told ET Magazine that he is seeing signs of revival of the capital expenditure cycle of companies in India but there are some drags such as a slowdown in China. Businessmen are adept at making the most of a chequered field but only if their businesses are fighting fit. Many marquee names of India Inc are in no shape to start big investments.




Rise & Fall with TidesA crackdown by the Reserve Bank of India on loan defaulters has virtually changed the face of India Inc.

Consider Essar steel, Reliance Communications, Electrosteel Steels, Bhushan Steel and Jaypee Group. All are facing action at the National Company Law Tribunal. ArcelorMittal is also set to take over Essar Steel. Or take Jet Airways, the one-time leader in Indian aviation which is now unable to manage its debt burden of `8,000 crore and contemplating a change in management. Around 23 of its aircraft — nearly a fifth of its fleet — have been grounded by lessors. Or consider Vedanta and its problems with its copper smelter plant in Tamil Nadu and its iron ore mining operations in Goa.


 The Chinese slowdown Ranade points to, for instance, may open up opportunities for Indian companies, it is also creating its own share of problems. Some Indian businesses were running on the back of the Chinese boom too.

Tata Motors’ scrip price rose and has now slipped as the performance of JLR, its subsidiary that accounts for the bulk of the automaker’s valuation, has slackened. In market capitalisation, Tata Motors tops the list of the Nifty companies with the biggest drops in the last two years.

R Gopalakrishnan, a former director of Tata Sons and author of several management books since retirement, says the problems of India Inc began with a period of hubris and misjudgment, where meaningless league tables of the ‘richest’ and the ‘biggest’ were bandied about.

“When the tides rose, every ship rose,” says Gopalakrishnan, recalling a 2012 speech by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh where he called for the release of “animal spirits” in business. “If you are on the dance floor, you have to keep tapping your feet. But suddenly, the music stopped and the carpet too was pulled out,” says Gopalakrishnan.


 Industrialist Harsh Goenka calls the decade-ago period as one of “adventurism” and says the action following implementation of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code is the best thing to have happened to India’s economy. “No promoter thought he would lose his company and many also created hurdles in the process.” Goenka says he expected capacity utilisation in India’s manufacturing sector to hit 85% by this time. (It is around 75% now, according RBI data). He also says businesses are forced to make capital investments when capacity utilisation touches 85% and expects that time to come by the end of this year.


Domino EffectTo make matters worse, the banking and financial sector saw a series of debacles in 2018. It began with the Letter of Credit scam at Punjab National Bank involving jeweller Nirav Modi followed by a default on debt payments by IL&FS, an infrastructure sector-focused non-banking financial company (NBFC), and ending with a housing finance meltdown towards. This year, Chanda Kochhar was sacked as CEO of ICICI Bank over allegations of misdemeanour.

The IL&FS default brought the country’s entire shadowbanking sector to its knees after other NBFCs faced a bank credit squeeze. As a result, short-term lending by NBFCs and mutual funds to companies whose promoters pledged their shares as security against borrowing came under the scanner. The selling of pledged shares by lenders led to a crash in scrip prices of Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd (ZEEL) as well as companies of the Reliance Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group. To induce stability and bring back confidence in the management Subhash Chandra, promoter of ZEEL, and the Wadhawans, promoters of Dewan Housing Finance Corporation, promised to induct strategic equity partners in their companies. There are few business groups in the country today that are ready to invest, except probably Gautam Adani-led Adani Enterprises, Sajjan Jindal-led JSW Steel and Mukesh Ambani-led Reliance Industries.


 Kolkata-based SREI Group, promoted by brothers Hemant and Sunil Kanoria, had to bear the brunt of the IL&FS crisis. The scrip of SREI Infrastructure tanked in the aftermath of the crisis and the group had to abandon its plan to list its equipment finance subsidiary.

“There is no long-term funding available for infrastructure projects or for other greenfield projects. Going forward, banks will not be in a position to indulge in term-lending,” SREI vice-chairman Sunil Kanoria told ET Magazine.

The tried-and-tested model of banks, flush with saving and current account deposits, funding large infrastructure or capacity addition by companies, has outlived its utility. There is no way to go back. Kanoria says that a new form of funding led by institutions, especially the ones in development finance, has to be developed.

It is a view echoed by Sandeep Upadhyay, MD of Centrum Infrastructure Advisory, an investment banking firm. He feels much of India’s infrastructure funding requirement will have to be catered by the likes of foreign sovereign and pension funds since they are better aligned to the sector’s riskreturn profile. “While many of these long term investment funds are evaluating buying out operational assets in India, there is limited interest to invest in greenfield projects. I guess it may take another year or two for these pension funds to cultivate interest in greenfield opportunities.”

Easy availability of credit in the last decade had led to a model where infrastructure projects were running on 75-80% debt funding. Much of the equity too was also debt money borrowed by the parent entity and infused into projects as equity, effectively increasing the debt component.

IL&FS itself was ticked off recently by accounting firm Grant Thornton that was asked to look into the lender’s books. The problem with highly leveraged financing is that there is little buffer left for miscalculations, and this is what afflicted India’s infrastructure and power sector leading to series of bankruptcies.


Not Full SteamSo if we ask: How is the mood inside India Inc and how many are raring to go and take up new opportunities, there are unlikely to be any straightforward answers.

Mining is a key area that brings in heavy investments. In an earlier interview to ET, Aditya Birla Group chairman Kumar Mangalam Birla had said that while allocation of natural resources had become more transparent, his group preferred a state-by-state approach as different states acted differently and their risk profiles varied.

A senior banker, who spoke to ET Magazine on condition of anonymity, agrees about the investment cycle restarting only in the third quarter of 2019-20 after a new government is in place. He said there is a fear psychosis, but the IBC, although imperfect, has brought in a sigh of relief.

There are structural issues too that companies needs to sort out amid the Income Tax department and the Enforcement Directorate coming down hard on corporate irregularities. Recognising this problem, the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) has been asking its members to sign a model code of conduct and business ethics document.




“Many actions of the government have helped. The Mauritius route of bringing in your own money has been virtually plugged. It has become tougher to do shady deals,” says Piruz Khambatta, chairman of Rasna and chairman of CII’s Western Regional Council. Khambatta is someone looking ahead at the election months. Summer is near, and for soft drink maker Rasna, it is an important season.

But every industrialist ET Magazine spoke to prefers to wait out the elections, and hopes for a “stable government” before taking any major decision.

BK Goenka, chairman of Welspun Group and president of Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India, feels bold decisions need time to settle down and businesses too need time to adjust to a new paradigm that excludes overleveraging. “If we get a stable government, the next five years can be golden years.”

KOLKATA/NEW DELHI: The appellate bankruptcy court has directed the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) to pronounce an order in the Bhushan Power & Steel insolvency case by March 31.

The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) issued the order on Friday, responding to an appeal by the company’s creditors who expressed concern over a delay in the insolvency process. Almost 1,800 operational creditors have approached the NCLT with their grievances.

JSW Steel, which has offered an upfront payment of Rs 19,300 crore to the lenders of Bhushan Power & Steel, has the overall approval of over 90 per cent of the committee of creditors. JSW’s offer includes another Rs 350 crore earmarked for operational creditors. Following the CoC’s nod, the resolution professional had issued a letter of intent to JSW Steel on February 12. JSW’s resolution plan remains to be approved by the NCLT.

The resolution process has been delayed on account of the appeals of operational creditors and a surprise last-minute bid by Bhushan Power & Steel’s promoter Sanjay Singal, who has offered a settlement to the lenders to clear their dues.

Singal has filed the settlement offer and demanded that the NCLT hear his plea.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 0.50 point, or 0.001 per cent, higher at 11,384, indicating a flat start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today's trade: 


Zee Entertainment: According to a media report, promoters may sell 20 per cent stake in Zee to Sony for Rs 13,000 crore. The amount will be used to repay debt. 


Lupin: USFDA has classified the inspection conducted at the company's Mandideep (Unit 1) facility in December as 'Official Action Indicated' (OAI). The facility could be subject to regulatory or administrative action. 


Mindtree, L&T Infotech: L&T Infotech (LTI) is likely to sign a deal with Café Coffee Day founder VG Siddhartha and his associates in the next four days to buy their 21 per cent stake in Mindtree, people briefed on the matter said.


DHFL: Private equity firms Kedaara Capital and Warburg Pincus have emerged as the highest bidders for Avanse Financial Services, an educational services financier owned by the holding company of DHFL. Meanwhile, NHB has concluded its inspection of books for DHFL's alleged misappropriation of loans.


PNB: Punjab National Bank has put its stake in CRIF High Mark, a credit information company that tracks individual and corporate payment history, on sale as it looks to sell all non-core investments and offset the delay in monetising its stake in life insurance business.


Wipro: Azim Premji said all earnings from 34 per cent shares worth about Rs 52,750 crore ($7.5 billion) — would be transferred to the endowment that supports the Azim Premji Foundation. With this, Premji has committed earnings from 67 per cent of Wipro’s shares to his charitable foundation. 


Jet Airways: Three airline, which is in the midst of restructuring its operations, has become a standard account for most of the lenders as it has begun meeting payment in the past two months, said two people familiar with the matter.


PFC, REC: International lenders have given their go-ahead to Power Finance Corp's nearly Rs 14,000-crore proposal to buy out REC Ltd for a high fee, clearing the final hurdle for the deal which is crucial for the government to meet its disinvestment target.

HCL Technologies: The IT major will acquire Strong-Bridge Envision in a bid to enhance Digital Transformation Consulting capabilities. 


Reliance Industries: A US subsidiary of RIL has stopped all business with Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA), the state-owned oil company of Venezuela, to comply with US sanctions on the Latin American country, an RIL spokesperson said.


Larsen & Toubro: The company's image with customers hinges on a transparent probe into its alleged involvement in the Cognizant bribery case, as India’s biggest engineering group expands its business to cement its credentials as a global technology leader.


IPO WATCHThe initial public offer (IPO) by miniratna MSTC got off to a slow start on Wednesday, with the issue receiving bids for 8,10,180 shares by 5 pm, which was 5 per cent of the total issue size of 1,76,70,400 shares. At the upper price band of Rs 121-128 per, the issue size is Rs 226 crore. 


Board meetings



Analyst calls
• CLSA has upgraded DLF to buy from sell and revised target price to Rs 229 from Rs 167. After adding debt at a Rs 8-10 billion/quarter pace for four plus years, DLF’s consecutive quarters of flat debt trend on breakeven cashflows marks a long-lasting turn, said CLSA. 

HSBC has initiated coverage on Ramco Cements with a target price of ₹540. The second largest cement producer in the south of India suffers from a lack of pricing power due to low capacity utilisation, said HSBC.

• Emkay Global has maintained buy rating on Cholamandalam Investment with a target price of Rs 1,572. The brokerage remains confident of Cholamandalam Investment’s ability to achieve 25 per cent CAGR growth in disbursements for FY18-FY20, driven by market share gains, deepening rural penetration, and product diversification. 

• CLSA has assumed coverage on Arvind Fashions with a target price of Rs 1,294. Arvind Fashions is a diversified play on India’s branded apparel market with a range of brands, predominantly casual and denim wear, and a play on value retailing (Unlimited) and other niche segments, said CLSA. 

• Kotak Securities has maintained its add rating on Mahindra CIE with an unchanged fair value of Rs 265, valuing the company at 15 times December 2020 estimated EPS. The company expects doubledigit growth in revenues over the next two years due to strong growth in the exports business.

KOLKATA: The Indian Steel Association (ISA), which represents top local makers of the alloy, has urged New Delhi to take immediate steps to ban imports from Iran after a near five-fold increase in shipments that might be traced back to the Persian Gulf nation.

Imports have increased after the imposition of US sanctions on Tehran, the ISA said last week, adding that the trend may have serious implications under CAATSA (Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act).

Furthermore, surging imports from Iran via the UAE at ‘predatory’ prices have added to the worries of Indian steel companies, the ISA said in a letter to steel secretary Binoy Kumar.




“Steel imports, whether directly from Iran or via transhipment (through) the UAE, should be banned since this trade is in grave violation of US sanctions, which can attract retaliatory measures by the US against India,” ISA secretary general Bhaskar Chatterjee said in the letter seen by ET.

ISA members include JSW Steel, Tata Steel, JSPL, Steel Authority of India and Essar Steel.

Over the past eight years, Iran has steadily raised output while demand locally has shrunk for the tenth largest global producer of the infrastructure alloy. Surplus capacity has climbed to 12.2 mt, or 36%, even as per capita consumption has gone down by 14%. Iran exports 30% of its steel to ASEAN, posing a threat of diversion to India.

While imports from Iran into India went up 66% in 2017-18, in 2018-19 there had been nil imports until December 2018. However, imports were reportedly routed via the UAE with change in country-origin. “It is alarming to note that exports from the UAE, a net importing country, have suddenly surged 390%, including 65,000 tonnes of flat steel products, for which the UAE is conventionally a net importer. This establishes the linkage of transhipment of Iranorigin steel via the UAE,” the steel association said.

Iran’s top three steel companies, which have a 64% share of production, belong to state-owned Iranian Mining and Mining Industries Development and Renovation Organisation on which US sanctions apply, ISA said.

NEW DELHI: Around 21 stocks rose to touch their 52-week highs on NSE in Tuesday's session.

Among the stocks that touched their 52-week highs were Alok Industries, Arvind Fashions, Axis Bank, Cantabil Retail India, Fine Organic Industries and Future Lifestyle Fashions.

Godfrey Phillips India, ICICI Bank, IDFC First Bank, The Karnataka Bank, Oriental Bank of Commerce, Power Finance Corporation, PVR, REC and Reliance Industries also featured among the stocks that touched their 52-week highs on NSE.

Benchmark NSE Nifty index was trading 8.20 points up at 11,470.40 while the BSE Sensex was trading 33.01 points up at 38,128.08. 

Overall, 31 shares were trading in the green in Nifty50 index, while 18 were trading in the red. In the Nifty 50 index, Bharti Infratel, ONGC, Hindalco Industries, Dr. Reddy's Lab and SBI were among the top gainers. 

While Eicher Motors, Larsen & Toubro, Hero MotoCorp, Adani Ports SEZ and JSW Steel were trading in the red.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 18 points, or 0.16 per cent, higher at 11,529.50, indicating a positive start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks, which may buzz the most in today's trade:


L&T, Mindtree: L&T has entered into a deal to buy Cafe Coffee Day owner V G Siddhartha's 20.32 per cent stake in Mindtree and has also placed an order with brokers to pick up another 15 per cent of the company shares from the open market. Subsequent to these deals, L&T would make an open offer to buy additional 31 per cent stake through an open offer.


Jet Airways: Etihad Airways is believed to have formally conveyed to Jet Airways’ top lender State Bank of India that it won’t make any further investment in the airline.


RCom: Nearly 15 months after Anil Ambani agreed to sell assets of Reliance Communications to a telecom firm run by elder brother Mukesh, the two groups Monday called off the deal citing delays in approval from the government and lenders.


Real estate stocks: The GST Council in its 34th meeting to be held on Tuesday is expected to take up various issues, including the implementation of lower GST rates for the real estate sector.


Hotel Leela Venture: The company announced sale of four hotels, including one in the national capital, and a property to Canadian investment fund Brookfield Asset Management for Rs 3,950 crore.


Tata Motors: UK arm Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is recalling over 44,000 units in the UK to rectify emission issues in models manufactured between 2016-19.


Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone (APSEZ): The company said its board has given nod for buyback of non-convertible debentures (NCDs) worth Rs 1,400 crore.


Tata Chemicals: The company has signed a non- exclusive agreement with the Indian Space Research Organisation for the latter's lithium-ion cell technology.


ZEEL, Voda Idea: Vodafone Idea and Zee Entertainment Enterprises (ZEEL) have entered into a tie-up on the latter’s over-the-top (OTT) platform ZEE5, in a bid to raise content play to take on rivals Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel.


Eclerx Services: Retail investors could make 12-30 per cent in Eclerx Services over the next three months through arbitrage after the technology process management company last week announced a buyback of its shares.


IPO WATCH
The initial public offering (IPO) by Embassy Office Parks REIT got subscribed 20 per cent on the first day of the offer on Monday. The public offer received bids for 1,39,30,400 shares till 5 pm as against the total issue size of 7,12,56,400 shares offered by the company.


Board meetings



Analyst calls

• Kotak Securities has recommended to buy Engineers India with a target price of Rs 153 as they believe EIL stock is trading at cheap valuation at PER 14x FY 2020 core earnings. EIL management reiterated positive outlook on the domestic order inflows driven by brownfield expansion of refineries, set up & integration of petrochemical plants with existing refineries and greenfield refinery expansion- including Maharashtra Refinery. 

 • Morgan Stanley has upgraded the rating of Kotak Mahindra Bank to overweight and raised the target price to ₹1,600 from Rs 1,365. The key factors, according to Morgan Stanley for the upgrade includes return of pricing power at private banks, partly helped by higher rates in wholesale markets and the funding crisis at NBFCs, improving credit risk situation in the corporate/SME segment. 

 • Reliance Securities has maintained its buy recommendation on ACC with a marginally revised target price of Rs 1,720. The brokerage continues to maintain their positive view on ACC owing to its deep penetration in the rural markets and consistent focus on premium products. 

• Geojit has downgraded the rating of Cadila Healthcare to hold with a revised target price of ₹358 based on 18x FY21E EPS. Highly leveraged balance sheet post Heinz India acquisition, which was funded largely through debt, remain a near term concern. 

• ICICI Securities has downgraded the ratings of Sterlite Technologies to hold and cut the target price to ₹230 per share citing pricing pressure. Some rub-off of steep correction in fibre optic cable prices in China and in other geographies may result in some downward revision of prices when they come to renegotiation, said the brokerage.

NEW DELHI: Headline indices Sensex and Nifty opened with healthy gains on Tuesday as investor sentiment remained positive on hopes of that the US Fed will sound dovish in its policy meet.

Rupee's gain against the US dollar, FPIs inflows and easing crude oil remained among other factors that underpinned the rally in the market.

Foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) bought Rs 1,822.99 crore worth of domestic stocks on Monday, data available with NSE suggested.

Even as the market is cheering the improved prospects of Narendra Modi-led NDA coming back to power after general elections 2019, an opinion poll by Times Now-VMR gave a boost to this anticipation.

The survey predicted the NDA to get 283 seats - 10 over the halfway mark - leaving the Congress-led UPA with only 135 seats. 

After jumping nearly 150 points in opening deals, Sensex pared some gains and traded 58 points, or 0.15 per cent, up at 38,153, while Nifty was 14 points, or 0.12 per cebt, up at 11,476 around 9:30 am.

The BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices were 0.29 per cent and 0.31 per cent up, respectively, at that time. 

Sun Pharma, Bharti Airtel, State Bank of India, ONGC, ITC and Reliance Industries were among the top gainers in the Sensex index. 

On the other hand, Hero MotoCorp, Bajaj Auto, LArsen & Toubro, Vedanta, ICICI Bank and Tata Steel were among the top losers in the Sensex kitty.

Out of total 31 stocks (including Tata Motors DVR) in the Sensex pack, 17 were trading with gains and 14 were incurring losses. 

Among the sectoral indices on BSE, capital goods, metal, auto and industrials were trading in the red. 

In the 16-share BSE Auto pack, only four stocks - Balkrishna Industries, Mahindra & Mahindra, MRF and Bharat Forge - were in the green.

Hero MotCorp, Eicher Motors, Maruti, Bajaj Auto, TVS Motors and Tata Motors were among the top drag on the auto index. 

In the metal pack, JSW Steel, Hindustan Zinc, Vedanta, Jindal Steel and Tata Steel were incurring losses.

NEW DELHI: Sugar stocks were trading in the negative zone in Tuesday's afternoon session.

Indian Sucrose (down 5 per cent), SBEC Sugar (down 5 per cent), MAGADHSUGAR (down 4.95 per cent), Dharani Sugars & Chemicals (down 4.56 per cent) and Empee Sugars & Chemicals (down 4.39 per cent) slipped up to 5 per cent.

Piccadily Sugar & Allied Inds (down 3.51 per cent), Triveni Engineering & Industries (down 3.35 per cent), BAJAJHIND (down 2.73 per cent), Uttam Sugar Mills (down 2.61 per cent), Dhampur Sugar Mills (down 2.39 per cent), KCP Sugar & Industries (down 2.29 per cent) and Ugar Sugar Works (down 2.27 per cent) too were down at least 2 per cent.

The NSE Nifty50 index was trading 49.90 points up at 11,512.10 while the 30share BSE Sensex was up 203.81 points at 38,298.88. 

Bharti Infratel (up 3.68 per cent), NTPC (up 3.00 per cent), Oil And Natural Gas Corporation (up 2.88 per cent) and ITC (up 2.06 per cent) were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack. 

On the other hand, Eicher Motors (down 2.21 per cent), Hero MotoCorp (down 1.93 per cent), Larsen & Toubro (down 1.87 per cent), JSW Steel (down 1.68 per cent) and Bajaj Auto (down 1.07 per cent) were trading in the red.

NEW DELHI: Auto shares were trading in the red in Tuesday's morning session.

Shares of TVS Motor Company (down 3.19 per cent), Eicher Motors (down 2.65 per cent), Hero MotoCorp (down 2.03 per cent) and Bajaj Auto (down 1.56 per cent) were the top losers in the index. 

Ashok Leyland (down 1.14 per cent ), Maruti Suzuki India (down 1.01 per cent), Mahindra & Mahindra (down 1.00 per cent) and Tata Motors (down 0.94 per cent) too were trading with losses. 

The Nifty Auto index was trading 1.13 per cent down at 8529.20 around 10:00 am. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 2.20 points at 11,464.40 while the BSE Sensex was up 36.51 points at 38,131.58.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 29 were trading in the green, while 21 were in the red. 

Shares of Bank of Baroda, Aditya Birla Capital, NTPC, Indian Oil Corp, SAIL, SBI, Ashok Leyland, YES Bank, Sun Pharma, ONGC, Vedanta, JSW Steel, Petronet LNG, Tata Motors and RIL were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: Metal stocks were trading with losses in Wednesday's session, keeping their sectoral index on NSE in the negative zone.

Shares of Jindal Steel & Power (down 3.94 per cent) , NMDC (down 3.57 per cent) , Tata Steel (down 2.84 per cent) and Steel Authority of India (SAIL) (down 2.24 per cent) were trading with losses. 

Hindustan Copper (down 2.17 per cent) , JSW Steel (down 1.80 per cent) , MOIL (down 1.62 per cent) and Coal India (down 1.40 per cent) too were trading lower. 

The Nifty Metal index was trading 1.14 per cent down at 2992.80 around 12:28 pm. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 26.80 points at 11,505.60 while the BSE Sensex was down 29.18 points at 38,334.29. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 15 were trading in the green, while 35 were in the red.

NEW DELHI: FMCG shares were trading lower in Wednesday's afternoon session.

Shares of Tata Global Beverages (down 1.82 per cent) , Britannia Industries (down 0.81 per cent) , United Spirits (down 0.75 per cent) , and Procter & Gamble Hygiene & Healthcare (down 0.63 per cent) were the top losers in the index. 

Marico (down 0.54 per cent) , Dabur India (down 0.50 per cent) , Godrej Consumer Products (down 0.44 per cent) and ColgatePalmolive (India) (down 0.10 per cent) too were trading with losses. 

The Nifty FMCG index was trading 0.08 per cent down at 30,408.80 around 12:37 pm.

NEW DELHI: Caution crept into Dalal Street on Wednesday ahead of the outcome of US Fed’s rate-setting meeting, and domestic equity benchmarks took a breather, tracking lacklustre global cues. 

Crude oil prices firmed up due to supply cut by the Opec club, giving investors another reason to turn cagey. Sensex ended the day with a nominal gain of 23 points, or 0.06 per cent, at 38,386, but Nifty slipped 11 points, or 0.10 per cent, to close at 11,521.

Midcaps and smallcaps reflected bearish sentiment, as their sectoral indices on BSE fell up to 0.36 per cent.

Here’s a lowdown on the key highlights of the session:


Embassy REIT IPO oversubscribedEmbassy Office Parks REIT’s initial public offering to raise around Rs 4,750 crore was oversubscribed on the last day. As of 4 pm, the issue, India’s first such listing, had 2.47 times subscription, NSE data showed. The issue had opened on Monday. 


Nirav Modi's arrest lifts PNB stockShares of Punjab National Bank closed 3.37 per cent higher at Rs 93.55 after reports that London Metropolitan Police had arrested scam accused Nirav Modi two days after Westminster Magistrate’s Court had issued an arrest warrant against him. Modi is the main accused in the $2 billion PNB scam. 


Voda Idea goes rights issue wayVodafone Idea, the board of India’s largest telecom operator by subscriber base, approved raising of up to Rs 25,000 crore through a rights issue. The issue price is set at Rs 12.50 per share, a Rs 2.50 premium over the face value of Rs 10. The stock closed 3.13 per cent higher at Rs 33. 


Jet shares fall for second dayShares of Jet Airways extended losses into the second straight session, finishing with a loss of 4.82 per cent at Rs 218. The stock came under pressure after its partner Etihad expressed its desire to exit the airline. The Abu Dhabi carrier has asked SBI to purchase its stake in the airline.


157 stocks look bearishAs many as 157 stocks, including Suzlon Energy, SAIL, Jet Airways, Adani Power, Tata Steel, JSW Steel, SREI Infrastructure and Bharat Forge, showed bearish crossovers on momentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD charts on BSE. On the other hand, 44 stocks, including Infosys, Spicejet, Reliance Naval, Apollo Hospitals and Oberoi Realty, witnessed bullish crossovers.


70 stocks enter oversold zoneMomentum oscillator Relative Strength Index, or RSI, showed 70 stocks including Palm Jewels, India Finsec, Cura Technologies, Anupam Finserv and JJ Finance Corp entered the oversold zone on BSE. On the other hand, Sunteck Realty, Alok Industries, UPL, Orient Tradelink and Esaar (India) were among 44 stocks that entered the overbought zone. 


222 stocks hit lower circuitsTata Steel, Adlabs Entertainment, Tinna Trade, Nitin Fire Protection Industries and Darshan Orna were among 222 stocks that hit lower circuits on BSE, while 200 stocks, including Reliance Communications, Nelco, Hotel Leela, Kwality and Mahamaya Steel Industries hit upper circuits.

NEW DELHI: Indian equity, forex, debt and commodity markets are closed on Thursday on account of Holi. 

Domestic equity benchmarks signalled indecisiveness on Wednesday as the Sensex ended higher for the eighth straight session while the Nifty closed in the red.

Caution crept in ahead of the outcome of the US Fed rate review and investors booked profit in select pockets. 

After fluctuating between gains and losses, the 30-stock pack settled at 38,387, up 23 points, or 0.06 per cent, with 12 stocks flashing green and 18 red. 

The Nifty closed 11 points down at 11,521, with 16 stocks advancing and 34 declining.

The Nifty50 formed higher highs and lows for the eighth successive session on Wednesday. However, analysts said it was too early to say if the market is about to see a trend reversal. 

"Nifty50’s near-term uptrend is intact and the next short-term upside resistance to be watched is at 11,605," said Nagaraj Shetti, technical research analyst of HDFC securities.

Momentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bearish crossovers on 157 counters on the BSE, including those of Suzlon Energy, SAIL, Jet Airways, Adani Power, Tata Steel, JSW Steel, SREI Infrastructure and Bharat Forge.

One invests in the market either by buying individual stocks through a broker or by putting money in equity funds or exchange traded funds. Brokerages are now offering investors a chance to buy an entire portfolio of stocks, built around a curated theme, in one shot. Can investors benefit from this emerging alternative?Based on a platform created by Bengaluru-based Smallcase Technologies, this avenue allows investors to take exposure to professionally researched, diversified theme-based portfolios with their existing trading and demat accounts. Seven brokers are offering this platform at present, including HDFC Securities, Kotak Securities, Edelweiss, 5paisa, Axis Securities and Zerodha. The underlying securities are held in the demat account and investors have complete control as the smallcases are integrated with the trading accounts.How it worksFirst, access the smallcase platform offered by the broker. Next, choose a theme of your liking. You can see what stocks make up the portfolio and in what proportion, and the investment rationale. You can customise the smallcase, by adding or removing stocks. For instance, if you are keen to build a portfolio of companies benefiting from rural consumption, you can invest in the Rising Rural Demand smallcase, a readymade portfolio of around 15 stocks that derive a chunk of revenues or volumes from the hinterland. While some brokers offer curated smallcases, others allow investors to create their own smallcases.Once you have finalised the selection, you can buy the smallcase. The minimum amount depends on the price and weightage of individual stocks in the portfolio. The platform will place buy orders for all stocks, which will be executed immediately depending on liquidity. In case a few orders are not fulfilled owing to illiquidity or other reasons, the investor will be given the option to ‘repair’ the smallcase later, where fresh orders are placed for stocks whose orders were unfulfilled. Repairing is required to ensure the portfolio matches the original theme.Brokers charge a one-time fee of Rs 100 when you first invest in a smallcase. The transaction also attracts the usual brokerage charges. There will be no additional fees for further orders in the same smallcase, apart from cost for executing the trades.Best performing smallcase Bargain Buys gave 135% returns in the past 3 years    Company  Weight in portfolio   Birlasoft 10%   SJVN  10%   Take Solutions 10%   Meghmani Organics 10%   Gujarat State Fertilisers 10%   Gujarat Alkalies 10%   Time Technoplast 10%   MOIL  10%   National Aluminium  10%   NMDC 10% But Growth at Fair Price gave 43%, lagging behind the Nifty and average equity fund    Company  Weight in portfolio   DCM Shriram  11.11%   Insectidices India  11.11%   Navin Fluorine  11.11%   GM Breweries  11.11%   JSW Steel  11.11%   Muthoot Finance  11.11%   Parag Milk Foods  11.11%   Sonata Software  11.11%   West Coast Paper Mills 11.11% Source: Smallcase.comAll smallcases are rebalanced periodically— mostly quarterly—to ensure the portfolio only constitutes companies that remain true to the broader theme. Existing investors can rebalance the portfolio by buying the incoming names and selling the outgoing companies in one shot. The investor can also exit the entire smallcase at any time or sell individual stocks within the smallcase separately. Investors can set up a SIP in each smallcase, where they can put a fixed amount every month in the chosen portfolio after the initial investment.Should you considerWhen buying stocks directly from brokers, investors retain control on what goes into the portfolio but have to execute trades separately. Identifying good quality stocks can be tricky. Taking the mutual fund route provides convenient access to a well-researched and diversified set of stocks, but at a higher cost. It also does not allow any control on the portfolio composition. Investing through smallcase is a middle ground. Arun Thukral, MD & CEO, Axis Securities, says, “This gives greater control and flexibility to the investor to modify the portfolio, enhancing his ability to influence the return.”This may be a worthwhile option for investors who wish to participate in themes or ideas not adequately represented in mutual funds. For instance, some of the initial smallcases launched by this platform included GST Opportunities, Smart Cities and Affordable Housing, when participation in these themes was not afforded by mutual funds. This also provide a good starting point for first-time investors who want to pursue a long-term approach to creating wealth. Returns from smallcases have been a mixed bag

Nandkishore Purohit, Head, Digital strategy and analytics, HDFC Securities, says the facility to rebalance the portfolio at regular intervals solves a big question for direct equity investors—knowing when to sell. “By providing for timely rebalancing, the platform ensures that the investor sells stocks at the right time and enters better stocks,” he adds.However, being thematic in nature, this avenue is more suited to savvy investors who can keep track of trends and understand the underlying themes. “The focused exposure to a theme, even through a diversified basket of stocks, can backfire if it doesn’t play out as expected,” cautions Thukral.For investors who are less involved, mutual funds should remain the preferred route to equities.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 63 points, or 0.55 per cent, lower at 11,407, indicating a gap-down start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks, which may buzz the most in today’s trade:


Mindtree: Independent directors at Mindtree have voiced their concerns about the board not having a “collective and informed stand” on what is seen as a hostile takeover attempt by L&T. The IT company’s board will discuss seeking a meeting with the engineering conglomerate.


Tech Mahindra: The Rs 1,956-crore share buyback by Tech Mahindra will open for subscription on Monday. The IT major intends to buy back up to 2.06 crore shares at Rs 950 a share. The offer will close on April 5.


Dr Reddy’s Laboratories: The drug maker said the USFDA has completed inspection at research and development facility of Aurigene Discovery Technologies and issued no form 483. 


Jet Airways: As lenders moved in to take charge of cash-strapped Jet Airways, lead banker SBI may ask a retired senior banker to head the airline and guide it out of the financial mess.


Tata Motors: Automobile major 
Tata
Motors will increase prices of its passenger vehicles range by up to Rs 25,000 starting April 2019.


Finolex Cables: Finolex group’s Chahbria family feud has worsened with Prakash Chhabria, son of late Prahlad Chhabria, founder of the Pune-based Rs 15,000 crore Finolex group, moving the Bombay High Court, questioning the continuance of Deepak Chhabria as executive chairman of Finolex Cables.


Reliance Infra: The promoter group entity of Reliance Infrastructure has pledged 1.56 per cent of the company's shares, according to a regulatory filing. Reliance Project Ventures and Management had on March 6 pledged 41 lakh shares.


RCom: Reliance Communications has pledged 4.52 per cent of its holding in Reliance Communications (RCom) amounting to 12.50 crore shares with IndusInd Bank Ltd, according to a regulatory filing.


Jyoti Structures: The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) has set aside the order to liquidate Jyoti Structures and asked the Mumbai bench of NCLT to consider the Rs 4,000-crore resolution plan submitted by Sharad Sanghi and others.


Reliance Industries: The operator of the world's largest oil refining complex, on Friday said in a statement it was not breaching US sanctions against Venezuela.


Karnataka Bank: The bank said it has reported to regulator RBI about a fraud amounting to Rs 13.26 crore in the fund-based working capital facility extended to SRS Finance.


Power Grid: State-owned Power Grid Corporation said Friday that it has paid Rs 1,629.62 crore as interim dividend for 2018-19 to the central government.


Alkem Laboratories: Drug firm Alkem Laboratories said it has received a letter from the US health regulator asking not to manufacture a particular product at its St Louis facility till a final decision is taken.


Board meetings





ADRS/GDRs
ADRs of Tata Motors plunged 5.26 per cent on Friday. They were followed by Dr Reddy's Labs, Vedanta, ICICI Bank, Wipro and Infosys, which fell up to 3 per cent. 


Analyst calls

• Emkay Global has a sell rating on Eicher Motors with a target price of Rs 18,000. Royal Enfield volumes suffered a 10 per cent year-on-year decline over November 2018 and February 2019 despite the absence of negative one-off factors such as production losses due to labor strikes, said Emkay. 

• Citigroup has a neutral rating on Info Edge (India) with a target price of Rs 1,715. Info Edge reported muted EBITDA growth in the third quarter owing to elevated ad spends across recruitment, property and matrimonial businesses, said Citi. 

 • Kotak Securities has downgraded KNR Constructions to add from buy and revised target price to Rs 282 from Rs 239. The company has bagged around Rs 10 billion worth of new projects in the last one month and is on track to meet its guidance of adding Rs 20 billion of new orders in 3-6 months timeline, said Kotak Securities. 

• HSBC has initiated coverage on Aster DM Healthcare with buy rating and target price of Rs 205. Aster is among the largest healthcare providers in the Gulf Cooperation Council and India through its hospitals, clinics and pharmacies, said HSBC. The firm has estimated Aster’s GCC EBITDA to double in five years despite the current macro weakness in the region. 

• CLSA has a buy rating on Sadbhav Engineering with a target price of Rs 340. While the stock is up 45 per cent in the last one month led by risk on rally, CLSA sees more legs to the stock. One of the key catalysts is potential divestiture of 9/11 of 12 operating NHs in favour of a global strategic investor, said CLSA.

India's crude steel production fell by 1.4 per cent to 8.936 million tonnes (MT) in December 2018, according to official data.

The country had produced 9.067 MT crude steel in December 2017.

"Crude steel production stood at 8.936 MT in December 2018, down by 1.4 per cent over December 2017 and was down by 0.3 per cent over November 2018." the Joint Plant Committee (JPC) said in its latest report.

During April-December, state-run SAIL, Rashtriya Ispat Nigam, Tata Steel, Essar Steel, JSW Steel and Jindal Steel and Power together produced 47.462 MT, the report said, adding that the rest 31.522 MT came from other producers.

In December 2018, hot metal output stood at 6.158 MT, 2.6 per cent higher over 6.001 MT in the same month in 2017, the JPC said.

The country's pig iron production fell by 5.5 per cent to 0.530 MT in December 2018 from 0.561 MT in December 2017.

India has set an ambitious target of increasing its capacity to 300 MT by 2030-31.

The JPC, under the Ministry of Steel, is the only institution in the country that collects data on the iron and steel industry.

Shares of Steel Authority of India (SAIL) (down 3.19 per cent) , JSW Steel (down 2.57 per cent) , Jindal Steel & Power (down 2.52 per cent) , and Vedanta (down 2.42 per cent) were the top losers in the index.

Hindalco Industries (down 2.39 per cent) , Hindustan Zinc (down 1.71 per cent) , NMDC (down 1.68 per cent) and Jindal Stainless (Hisar) (down 1.65 per cent) too were trading in the red. 

The Nifty Metal index was trading 1.63 per cent down at 2934.55 around 10:57 am. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 98.60 points at 11,358.30 while the BSE Sensex was down 328.71 points at 37,835.90.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 11 were trading in the green, while 38 were in the red. 

Shares of SAIL, Indian Oil Corp, YES Bank, ONGC, NTPC, SBI, Bank of Baroda, Tata Motors, BEL, BHEL, Coal India, ICICI Bank, Ashok Leyland and Infosys were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

MUMBAI: JSW Group is entering the steel furniture business under the brand JSW Living, a venture that marks the induction of Tarini Jindal Handa into the group as the new entity’s managing director. The 35-year-old is the oldest daughter of JSW Group chairman Sajjan Jindal and brings with her expertise in design and marketing.

Jayant Acharya, director of commercial and marketing at JSW Steel, will helm the board as the company’s chairman while Bedraj Tripathy, a former senior executive of Godrej Interio, has been appointed as the chief executive. “The steel furniture foray is part of JSW Group’s diversification into consumer space. Through this and other upcoming initiatives, we are evaluating forays into the consumer space,” Acharya told ET in an emailed response to a query.


Tarini Jindal Handa The group did not specify the quantum of investment in the new venture, which is slated to be launched in the first quarter of 2019-20. It will enable the group to inch closer to being a more “consumerfacing” brand and also lead to further value addition in the company’s flagship steel business, said people aware of the matter.

With the launch of JSW Living, Tarini Jindal Handa will join brother Parth in revamping the company’s brand to enable it to reach home consumers directly. Parth Jindal is spearheading the movement through the group’s paints business, JSW Paints, which is yet to be launched. JSW Steel has also launched colour coated roofs under the brand Colouron+.

JSW Living will focus largely on the home furniture segment, which accounts for almost 65% of the total furniture sales in the country. It is expected to follow a three-tier selling and distribution strategy to target top 100 towns in India, the people said.

India’s furniture market is growing at a compound annual growth rate of more than 11% in the past five years.
